raw_text:
Davenport hits out at Wimbledon
 
 World number one Lindsay Davenport has criticised Wimbledon over the issue of equal prize money for women.
 
 Reacting to a disputed comment by All England Club chairman Tim Phillips, the American said: "I think it is highly insulting if prize money is taken away. "Somebody, I think it was Mr Phillips, said they won't have money for flowers at Wimbledon. That's insulting." An All England club spokesperson denied Phillips made the remark, insisting: "He definitely didn't say it." The statement added: "It was said by someone else and was a humorous aside at the end of a radio interview when the conversation had moved to talking about the Wimbledon grounds."
 
 Davenport was speaking following the announcement that this week's Dubai Duty Free event will join the US and Australian Opens in offering equal prize money for women. "You hear about women playing only three sets while men play five," said Daveport. "And the best women are never going to beat the best men. "But it's a different game you go to watch with the women - it doesn't make it better or worse. "Hopefully we will be able to change people's minds." Serena Williams, who is also in Dubai, added: "I'm obviously for equal prize money. "Women's tennis is exciting. Men's tennis is exciting as well, but the women have it right now. "If you are bringing in the spectators you should be able to reap what everyone else is able to reap."
llama3.2:1b:
Lindsay Davenport criticizes Wimbledon over equal prize money for women, saying it is insulting to take away flowers. A spokesperson denies this, claiming Phillips made a humorous remark about not having money for flowers at Wimbledon. 

Serena Williams also supports equal prize money for women, while men's tennis has more lucrative options for spectators.
llama3.2:3b: Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over the issue of unequal prize money for women, calling it "highly insulting". The club denied a comment by Tim Phillips that suggested taking away prize money was for flowers. The announcement of equal prize money in Dubai's tournament and other events has sparked debate about fairness in women's tennis.
gemma2:2b: Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over unequal prize money for women, calling it insulting and comparing it to the disparity in set lengths for men's and women's matches. She applauded the inclusion of equal prize money for women at events like the Dubai Duty Free event, and other players echoed this sentiment.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Davenport criticized Wimbledon over the issue of equal prize money for women. She said some people who won't receive money at Wimbledon may not get flowers, which she called insulting. The All England Club spokesperson denied Phillips made a comment. Both Davenport and Serena Williams agreed that it's about whether women's tennis is better than men's.
qwen2.5:1.5b: World No. 1 Lindsay Davenport criticizes Wimbledon over prize money disparity between men and women at the All England Club. Some officials deny Phillips' comment about reducing female prizes, but Davenport argues equal pay would undermine men's games. She supports increasing prize money for women events like Dubai Duty Free and encourages changing perceptions of women's tennis.
qwen2.5:3b: Lindsay Davenport criticizes Wimbledon for potential cuts in prize money for women players after a comment suggesting flowers might not be provided. She argues equal prize money, like at other major tournaments, would improve perceptions of women's tennis as exciting and fair. Williams also supports this move, emphasizing the appeal of female tennis matches.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Lindsay Davenport, world number one, criticized Wimbledon for its unequal prize money policy during a Dubai event, where she's participating. The controversy stems from an alleged remark by All England Club chairman Tim Phillips, which suggested flowers wouldn't be afforded due to limited funds, insulting the women's efforts. However, an All England club spokesperson denied Phillips made this comment, stating it was a humorous aside in a radio interview about Wimbledon grounds.

Davenport defended equal prize money for women, emphasizing that top female players can compete with men but highlighting the distinct appeal of watching women's tennis. She expressed hope that such events would change perceptions about women's tennis being inferior to men's. Serena Williams, a fellow participant and advocate for equal prize money, agreed, stating women's tennis is equally exciting and should receive equivalent prize money to attract spectators.
